replies.bodyText: If we did, yes, what I suggested is stupid :). If we didn't, it makes sense :).
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText:
No we did not.  The scheme got introduced only with the new way of configuring the Redis connection string.
Meaning that if the host does not contain it, the it's the old way of doing things and throwing an error won't be backward compatible anymore. Hence me the need to re-construct the connection string as it was previous done.
Maybe I am missing something.
replies.author: machi1990

replies.bodyText:
I added my comment at exactly the place I wanted us to throw the error.
If address contains :// then it's the new way of doing things so, in this case if any of these fields is defined we could throw an error? Or am I missing something?
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText: (Note that I might be missing something, I'm exhausted :))
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText:
I added my comment at exactly the place I wanted us to throw the error.
If address contains :// then it's the new way of doing things so, in this case if any of these fields is defined we could throw an error? Or am I missing something?

I get your comment now.
Sorry it took me long to realize it since the comment appear just after the return address; statement  and I read your comment all wrong - (that it concerned the old way).
Yes, you are right we could throw.  I think the old way made it impossible to define the host with the scheme  i.e :// part. So if they enter that line, it is by following the new way of doing things and chances are low that they'll mix it with the deprecated configs since they'll be hidden. If it happens to be the case,  I think we can be lenient here and just start the application with the right configuration and ignore the old ones. They'll get a nice warning message if they keep on using the old property once we remove them post 1.9.x release.
Hope it makes sense.
replies.author: machi1990
